meaning_mnemonic:
What happens when <kanji>light</kanji> travels a <kanji>year</kanji>? You have a <vocabulary>light-year</vocabulary>.

光年 is typically used after a number to specify the vast distances between celestial objects, like 地球からこの星まで3光年です (it's 3 light-years from Earth to this star).

Something that is <kanji>obsolete</kanji> will end in <kanji>extinction</kanji>. Join in the calls for its <vocabulary>abolition</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>elimination</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>extinction</vocabulary>, whatever it is.
The <kanji>mountain</kanji> <kanji>peak</kanji>s are just the <vocabulary>mountains</vocabulary>. Just because you can only see the peaks doesn't mean the rest of the mountain doesn't exist.

泊まる is "to stay the night." Now you're letting someone else stay the night, which makes this <vocabulary>to let someone stay over</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to let someone stay the night</vocabulary>.

meanings.meaning: To Let Someone Stay The Night

meaning_mnemonic: This is a bit of a weird word. The kanji is <kanji>char</kanji>, and a previous word you learned (焦げる) is "to be burned." This, on the other hand, is "to be in a hurry" or "to be impatient." I guess if you're getting burned or have that feeling, you're going <vocabulary>to be in a hurry</vocabulary> and you're going <vocabulary>to be impatient</vocabulary>. You can tell that this is that word because it only has one kana, る, which stands for <reading>ru</reading>de. You're feeling someone is being rude (or maybe you are), which is why you have this feeling of impatience and hurrying.

You know that 裂く is "to tear" or "to rip up." So, if you're trying to tear or rip up something, and you're <kanji>pull</kanji>ing it at the same time, you are going <vocabulary>to tear up</vocabulary> that thing, or more accurately perhaps <vocabulary>to tear off</vocabulary> something, since you're pulling.
分裂 means "split" or "division." The <kanji>nucleus</kanji> version of this split is <vocabulary>nuclear fission</vocabulary>.
Remember how 襲撃 is an <kanji>assault</kanji> or <kanji>attack</kanji>? This is the verb form, so it's <vocabulary>to attack</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to assault</vocabulary>.

A <kanji>far</kanji> <kanji>distance</kanji> <kanji>detach</kanji>ment is a distance that is far. It is <vocabulary>long distance</vocabulary>. Also remember that 距離 is a "distance" so a far distance is a <vocabulary>long distance</vocabulary>.
A 距離 is a <kanji>distance</kanji> and 近 is <kanji>near</kanji>. A near distance is a <vocabulary>short distance</vocabulary>.
A 距離 (<kanji>distance</kanji>) that is <kanji>short</kanji> is a <vocabulary>short distance</vocabulary>.

Remember how 戸籍 is the family register? This is referring to that, and that makes this word <vocabulary>entry in family register</vocabulary>. In most cases, that specifically means a <vocabulary>registration of marriage</vocabulary> in that family register.

一斉 is <kanji>simultaneous</kanji> or <kanji>all at once</kanji>. Add the に in there and you're heading towards those things. For "simultaneous" that becomes <vocabulary>simultaneously</vocabulary>. For "all at once" it stays at <vocabulary>all at once</vocabulary>.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>destroy</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to be destroyed</vocabulary>. You know you're not destroying things because of the <reading>beer</reading> (びる). You'd never destroy beer... but someone else might. Grrr.

This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>stiff</kanji>? It's <vocabulary>stiff</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>hard</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>firm</vocabulary>.

Keep something <kanji>stiff</kanji> and <kanji>straight</kanji> and it's naturally going to lead to <vocabulary>stiffness</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>stiffening</vocabulary>.

硬直 commonly describes a person's body becoming stiff, whether from shock or discomfort, or due to the onset of rigor mortis following death.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>earnings</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to earn income</vocabulary>, because you can't "to income" something. Can also be <vocabulary>to make money</vocabulary>.
Something with <kanji>lucidity</kanji> is clear. That's why this word is <vocabulary>to become clear</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to become transparent</vocabulary>.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well, though you'll want to know that this refers most specifically to <vocabulary>human skin</vocabulary>.
<kanji>Bird</kanji> <kanji>skin</kanji> is <vocabulary>goosebumps</vocabulary>. Makes sense, since a goose is a bird and a bird's skin is bumpy.

The <kanji>skin</kanji> <kanji>touch</kanji> is  the feeling of touching with your skin. That is <vocabulary>the touch of</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>feel of</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>texture</vocabulary> of something. It's what you feel when you touch your skin to something!

<kanji>Skin</kanji> <kanji>color</kanji> is <vocabulary>skin color</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>skin tone</vocabulary>.

This word originally referred to a pale orange or peach color, and sometimes you'll still see it used that way. But labeling that as 肌色 wasn't inclusive of all skin tones. Now, it simply refers to skin color in general.

A <kanji>small</kanji> <kanji>boat</kanji> is a <vocabulary>boat</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>small craft</vocabulary>. If something is a "big boat" it's better to call it a "ship" I think, which is why this is just a <vocabulary>boat</vocabulary>.

The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Note that this word isn't usually used by itself (that would be 船). It's usually attached to things that are boat-related, but I wanted you to learn it individually so you can use it that way.

The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

鐘 usually refers to larger, open-ended <vocabulary>bell</vocabulary>s of the sort you might find in a church's bell tower or a Buddhist temple.

A <kanji>warn</kanji> <kanji>bell</kanji> is a bell that goes off when you need to be warned about something. This is usually an <vocabulary>alarm bell</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>fire bell</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>villain</kanji> <kanji>vessel</kanji> is a vessel used by a villain. This vessel holds bullets, and is a <vocabulary>dangerous weapon</vocabulary>.

The <kanji>origin</kanji> <kanji>villain</kanji> is the villain who's running everything. They're the mastermind behind the villainy going on. They're the <vocabulary>ringleader</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>main culprit</vocabulary>.

元凶 isn't just limited to people, so it can often refer to the <vocabulary>root cause</vocabulary> of a problem too, like 汚染の元凶 (the main cause of pollution). It carries a serious, negative tone and is mostly used in writing about crimes, scandals, or other major issues.
A <kanji>villain</kanji> who is <kanji>bad</kanji> is the most <vocabulary>atrocious</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>fiendish</vocabulary> villain of them all.
You have the noun version of <kanji>hunt</kanji>. That is <vocabulary>hunting</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>hunt</kanji> <kanji>person</kanji> is a person who hunts. A <vocabulary>hunter</vocabulary>.

The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. When used as a suffix, it means <vocabulary>approximate time</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>around</vocabulary> (as in "around 3:00").
The <kanji>previous</kanji> <kanji>approximate</kanji> was the previous approximate time, which is <vocabulary>recently</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>the other day</vocabulary>.

The <kanji>near</kanji> <kanji>approximate</kanji> is the approximate time that was near to you. This period of time is the <vocabulary>lately</vocabulary> period of time. It's <vocabulary>recently</vocabulary>.

The <kanji>year</kanji> <kanji>approximate</kanji> is your <vocabulary>approximate age</vocabulary>. This is also an indirect way to refer to <vocabulary>adolescence</vocabulary>, and when people reach <vocabulary>marriageable age</vocabulary>!
いつ is "when" and 頃 is "about." Combine those together and you have "<vocabulary>about when</vocabulary>?" or "<vocabulary>how soon</vocabulary>?"
<kanji>This</kanji> (この) <kanji>approximate</kanji> is this approximate time. It is <vocabulary>recently</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>nowadays</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>these days</vocabulary>.

The <kanji>young</kanji> <kanji>approximate</kanji> is the approximate age of when you were young. This, approximately, is <vocabulary>one's youth</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>early life</vocabulary>.

若い頃 is often used when fondly remembering the past, like, "When I was younger, I used to…"
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
When attached to a word, this refers to a ____ spirit. It's  the same meaning as the kanji, too.

The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

Wondering how 脚 and 足 differ? You might remember 足 is mostly for feet but can sometimes refer to legs. 脚 refers to the whole <vocabulary>leg</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>lower limb</vocabulary> (often including the foot). Basically, go with 足 for feet and 脚 for legs!

A <kanji>leg</kanji> <kanji>book</kanji> is just the legs of a book. Not a whole book. It only contains the parts that walk around and move, not so much the descriptions (things that don't move). This kind of book is a <vocabulary>script</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>screenplay</vocabulary>. These "books" are focused on actions and things people say, which is why it's just the legs.

It's <kanji>possible</kanji> that it's <kanji>considerably</kanji> considerable. It's <vocabulary>considerably</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>fairly</vocabulary>, and <vocabulary>quite</vocabulary>... something. Also please note that this is almost always written in kana and not kanji. But, we're learning kanji here, so gosh darn it we're going to learn some kanji.
Despite looking like an adjective this is a noun. It means the same thing as the kanji: <vocabulary>curse</vocabulary>.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>curse</kanji>, and the verb version is <vocabulary>to curse</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to put a curse on</vocabulary>.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

The <kanji>former</kanji> <kanji>calendar</kanji> is the calendar from before. It's the <vocabulary>lunisolar calendar</vocabulary> and the <vocabulary>traditional Japanese calendar</vocabulary>. Certainly not the current calendar, anyways.

In the <kanji>west</kanji>, a <kanji>calendar</kanji> shows the year according to the <vocabulary>common era</vocabulary>, aka the <vocabulary>Christian era</vocabulary>. You know, like 2025 CE (or 2025 AD) — we're 2000+ years into the common era.

This <vocabulary>Western calendar</vocabulary> differs from the traditional calendar of Japan, which names its eras for reigning emperors. The current Reiwa era followed the Heisei era, which came after the Showa era. Neat, right? On official forms in Japan, you can often choose whether to write your birth year in the Western or Japanese style.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>cloudy</kanji> and the verb vocab version means <vocabulary>to get cloudy</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to become cloudy</vocabulary>.

Aside from describing the weather, 曇る can also refer to other physical phenomena, like when your glasses or bathroom mirror gets fogged up. It can also be used figuratively, such as when someone's expression clouds over (表情が曇る) due to a negative emotion.

The noun version of <kanji>cloudy</kanji> is <vocabulary>cloudy weather</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>cloudiness</vocabulary>. In some cases, this can also refer to the type of <vocabulary>fog</vocabulary> you'd find on a window or your glasses.

Despite being a noun in Japanese, you'll actually see this translated as the adjective "cloudy" in English a lot. Don't let that fool you, though, it still behaves as a noun in Japanese! It's just another example of word types not quite matching up between English and Japanese.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>stare</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to stare at</vocabulary> (or <vocabulary>to look at</vocabulary> in a very staringish way).
You <kanji>stare</kanji> at <kanji>hope</kanji>. It looks good. That is your <vocabulary>prospect</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>view</vocabulary>, as you stare at hope.
You're <kanji>all</kanji> <kanji>naked</kanji>, which makes you <vocabulary>completely naked</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>totally naked</vocabulary>.
If you're <kanji>half</kanji> <kanji>naked</kanji> you're <vocabulary>half nude</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>half naked</vocabulary>.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>gamble</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to gamble</vocabulary>.

The noun version of <kanji>gamble</kanji> is <vocabulary>gambling</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>betting</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>a gamble</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>a bet</vocabulary>. Whatever you do, put it all on black 13. Trust me.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

A <kanji>righteousness</kanji> <kanji>cram school</kanji> is, for some reason, a <vocabulary>private school</vocabulary>. Maybe because they don't think the public cram schools are any good, so they take their righteousness somewhere else to start a private one? I'm not sure.

You may have seen the abbreviation 私学 (for 私立学校) as another word for private school. 私学 is typically used for any schools, elementary through university, that are run by individuals or private groups.

義塾 instead generally describes private schools founded during the Edo and Meiji periods. In contemporary Japanese, it's not really used on its own but can be seen in school names like 明徳義塾高等学校 (Meitoku Gijuku High School).
Remember how 学生 is "student"? This plays off that. A <kanji>cram school</kanji> "student" is a student of a cram school, a <vocabulary>cram school student</vocabulary>.

An <kanji>electricity</kanji> <kanji>table</kanji> is a <vocabulary>calculator</vocabulary>. Why is this? You can think about it in a couple of different ways. Maybe in the past, a calculator (aka abacus) would take up a whole table, making this "electric" version a calculator. Or, maybe it can be used to solve tables. Wrong kind of table, but should help you to remember the meaning of this word.
An <kanji>eat</kanji>ing <kanji>table</kanji> is a <vocabulary>dining table</vocabulary>.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

<kanji>Table</kanji> <kanji>sphere</kanji> is a sport where you have a table and then you use a sphere on it. That's <vocabulary>table tennis</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>ping pong</vocabulary>. Makes sense, right? You use a ping pong ball and you play on a table.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>polish</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to polish</vocabulary> or, strangely specifically (and we'll learn an even more specific word for this later) <vocabulary>to brush your teeth</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>polish</kanji> is a <vocabulary>polish</vocabulary> or even a <vocabulary>shine</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>thin</kanji> <kanji>bacteria</kanji> is... well... a <vocabulary>bacteria</vocabulary>. I guess all bacteria are really thin. So thin you can't see them with your naked eye, in fact.
A "ばい" <kanji>bacteria</kanji> is a <vocabulary>germ</vocabulary>. In case you're wondering, the ばい is referring to the kanji 黴, but people don't usually write that part.
Someplace with <kanji>nothing</kanji> amounts of <kanji>bacteria</kanji> is <vocabulary>sterilized</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>aseptic</vocabulary>.
If you <kanji>kill</kanji> <kanji>bacteria</kanji> you are performing <vocabulary>sterilization</vocabulary>. You're killing those bacteria.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Also means <vocabulary>shadow</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>shade</kanji> <kanji>energy</kanji> is a shady feeling. It's a feeling of <vocabulary>gloom</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>melancholy</vocabulary>.
An <kanji>evil</kanji> <kanji>ghost</kanji> isn't so much a ghost as it is an <vocabulary>evil spirit</vocabulary>.

A <kanji>ghost</kanji> <kanji>feeling</kanji> is <vocabulary>inspiration</vocabulary>. For some reason, the feeling of ghosts is the feeling of inspiration. I guess a ghost goes inside you and makes you feel this inspiration? Oh, wait, you can feel that because you have the <vocabulary>sixth sense</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>deceased</kanji> <kanji>ghost</kanji> is a <vocabulary>ghost</vocabulary> (all ghosts are deceased). Can also refer to "<vocabulary>the dead</vocabulary>."
A <kanji>ghost</kanji> <kanji>garden</kanji> is where many ghosts are harvested and where many ghosts grow. This is a <vocabulary>cemetery</vocabulary>.
An "<kanji>add</kanji> <kanji>damp</kanji>ness <kanji>container</kanji>" is a container that adds dampness to the air. That's a <vocabulary>humidifier</vocabulary>.

The <kanji>damp</kanji> <kanji>earth</kanji> is where water seems to congregate, but not so much that there's a lake or ocean or anything like that. Just damp. This is a <vocabulary>wetlands</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>damp</kanji> <kanji>energy</kanji> is a feeling of dampness. It is <vocabulary>moisture</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>humidity</vocabulary>.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>damp</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to be damp</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be moist</vocabulary>. Ewww.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>bride</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to marry</vocabulary>, because you can't really "to bride" someone.

嫁ぐ is often used when describing how someone has or is going <vocabulary>to marry into</vocabulary> another family.

The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

溝 is commonly used for physical gaps like drainage ditches, small trenches, or grooves in surfaces. It can also describe metaphorical gaps, like emotional or relational divides between people.
An <kanji>ocean</kanji> <kanji>gutter</kanji> is an <vocabulary>ocean trench</vocabulary>.

You already know that <kanji>emit</kanji>ted <kanji>water</kanji> means "drainage." Add <kanji>gutter</kanji> to that and this becomes a <vocabulary>drainage</vocabulary> in the sense of a <vocabulary>drainage ditch</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>gutter</vocabulary>.

When it comes to the drain in your sink or bathtub, you can use 排水口, which has the same pronunciation but a different kanji.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
A <kanji>waterfall</kanji> <kanji>river</kanji> is a river that's moving like a waterfall! Fast and furious! Water that moves like this are <vocabulary>rapids</vocabulary>.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>lunatic</kanji> or <kanji>crazy</kanji>. The verb version of this is <vocabulary>to go mad</vocabulary> (you don't really "go lunatic" now, do you?) or <vocabulary>to go crazy</vocabulary>.
<kanji>Lunatic</kanji> <kanji>energy</kanji> is <vocabulary>madness</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>insanity</vocabulary>.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji means <kanji>fly</kanji>, so the verb version means <vocabulary>to fly</vocabulary>.

Remember how 趣味 means "hobby"? Well, if you have <kanji>bad</kanji> hobbies, it probably means you have <vocabulary>bad taste</vocabulary>. 

悪趣味 is often used to describe something that lacks sophistication or sensitivity, like tacky shoes and offensive jokes, as well as someone with that kind of taste.
A 包み is a <kanji>bundle</kanji> or <kanji>package</kanji>, and 紙 is <kanji>paper</kanji>. What paper goes around bundles and packages? That would be <vocabulary>wrapping paper</vocabulary>.

The <kanji>tide</kanji> <kanji>time</kanji> is the <vocabulary>tidal hour</vocabulary>.

This word is often used figuratively, as in “the perfect time to act”, especially in reference to quitting something or backing away from a situation.

The <kanji>black</kanji> <kanji>tide</kanji> isn't what you think, most likely. This is the <vocabulary>Japan current</vocabulary>, aka the <vocabulary>Kuroshio Current</vocabulary>. It's a Northern flowing  current on the West side of the Pacific Ocean. Have you heard of the Gulf Stream? It's kind of like that.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>rub</kanji> and this verb means <vocabulary>to rub</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to scrub</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>small</kanji> <kanji>bundle</kanji> is merely a <vocabulary>package</vocabulary>. Something big would be a big package, I guess.

The kanji and the word are the same, so this can mean <vocabulary>lump</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>mass</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>bundle</vocabulary>. Additionally, this can also refer to being the <vocabulary>embodiment</vocabulary> of something. When somebody or something is a mass or bundle of some attribute or trait, they might as well be the embodiment of it!
When you control your <kanji>hand</kanji> an <kanji>approximate</kanji> amount, you are going to be a very <vocabulary>moderate</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>reasonable</vocabulary> person.

As usual, you can guess this is a verb thanks to the う sound on the end. The kanji means <kanji>frustration</kanji>, and unfortunately frustration tends <vocabulary>to torment</vocabulary> people. This verb is pretty advanced, but still useful to know!

auxiliary_meanings.meaning: To Be In The Service Of

meaning_mnemonic:
Everything we're <kanji>doing</kanji> is <vocabulary>to serve</vocabulary> you, you know.

This verb is a bit archaic and therefore has a formal feel to it. It's used to talk about serving emperors, kings, and gods, among others.

<kanji>Stiff</kanji> <kanji>freight</kanji> always has to be paid for in <vocabulary>coin</vocabulary>s, because coins are also stiff. You can't go paying for something stiff with something not stiff, that would make no sense at all.

I will <kanji>offer</kanji> you food and <kanji>stand</kanji> here while you eat it, because I curated this <vocabulary>menu</vocabulary> and I want to make sure you enjoy it.

This word doesn't mean the physical menu you get in a restaurant; rather, it refers to a <vocabulary>meal plan</vocabulary>, whether that means the sequence of courses for a single meal or the general meal plan for someone's entire week.
